comments.article: When are you coming to Montreal?!

Well, George came to Montréal 2 and a half years ago (for Worldcon). So it’s gonna probably be a very long while until (if ever) he comes back to the « Belle province ».

But you never know, maybe he’s had a favorable taste for Montréal and we’ll see him sooner rather than later. (but to be honest, I remember him ranting a bit about our hotels and hospitality... which I felt a bit sorry for at the time - So Toronto, tidy up your act will ya :¬)

On a side note... Probably a trip to Québec City would be a good thing for George though... With all the historic heritage and military installations (being north america’s oldest walled city, it’s relation with the narrowing river and all that...). When I read about Winterfell, I always have visions of Québec City.

comments.article:
I was the the Toronto book signing 6 years ago for Feast... you did personalizations back then. It was at the Worlds Largest Bookstore... which is a name, not a description, but is part of the chapters/indigo family... It was however a very big store, and we all got to wait inside. The event information for this signing warns the line up may extend outside.

Line ups suck. It should be a ticket system, and done in a mall. For instance, there is a nice Indigo books at the York Dale mall in Northern Toronto. It is on the subway line so super easy access. If it was still a lineup, there is something like 1.5-2 kilometers of interior hallways for line ups, not including room in the store. If it was a ticket system, you could go watch a movie or eat at a restaurant while waiting for the ticker to get close to your number. Imagine how civilized that would be!

comments.article:
Mr. Martin:

I was really hoping that I could make it to Toronto for a signing of your ADWD novel.
I had purchased 2 hard copies opening day in the hopes of having one signed at some point.
Alas, that day has come, and I unfortunately couldn’t justify spending the money to travel to Toronto more than once in a month(I'll explain).

I live in Windsor Ontario, and have a 3 year old child that was born at Sick Kids Hospital in Toronto, diagnosed with a Diagfragmatic Hernia, Hypoplaisia and Dextrocardia.
We now often travel back n' forth for appointments, rather than being accommodated by Toronto's Ronald McDonald House long term.

When I first read about your upcoming trip to T.O., I was hoping to find a way to make our Sick Kids appointment(later in the month...approx. 23rd) coincide to minimize costs.
This way I could finally thank you for providing a place to release my sorrows during these troubling times.
I am truly one of your greatest fans.
Unfortunately, the appointment could not be adjusted(which is understandable I suppose, Sick Kids is a busy place after all.).

Due to our frequent visits throughout each year, our finances are sadly depleted. These trips can be very costly for us, so regrettably we'll have to wait for another opportunity meet you.

So ultimately the reason I'm sending this message is to ask a question.
...and it took a bit to get here I know(sorry); I just felt compelled to explain.

The question is:
What are the odds that you'll be making a trip near Windsor sometime in the future, or perhaps returning to Toronto again?

Meeting you is on the top of my list of things to do, as your wonderful writings have helped to alleviate stress during numerous times of sadness.
Your novels have allowed me to escape to another place during the 15 years of my sister's illness/Sick Kids hospitalizations prior to her death 2 years ago(Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia).
They have obviously also helped throughout the many issues/hospitalizations with my son since his birth 3 years ago as well.
Also, they’ve helped with every time of death and/or feeling of hopelessness between and since then.
I wish I could say there hasn’t been many, but I cannot.
It’s been a bad 15-20 years to say the least.

Anyway...I will anxiously await your reply, however; even if your answer is not as I hope, I take this opportunity to thank you now.
I appreciate your skill as a writer, and your amazing ability to tell a story capable of captivating someone completely.
This is a talent that is very much desired when suffering times of heartache.
To me, it’s something invaluable that has helped me through the toughest of times...and for that I can honestly say I cannot ever thank you enough.
I realize that you didn't write these books for me specifically, though that doesn't negate the fact that they were therapeutic to me as the reader.

Have a wonderful day sir; I truly hope your time in Toronto is/was pleasant.


Steve

Dear George, it's been a few time I've so badly wanted to tell you this:
I've been writing stories for years and years now, and, well, I'm only starting to find interesting stuff in them, I'm only starting not to feel ashamed of me when I reread myself. There is such a journey ahead of a writer.
But, my point is that Asoiaf influenced me in a big way: I've restarted a new story, abandonning my previous one I was struggling with (hope one day I'll have the faith to finish it), and in this new one, I couldnt help but use your PoV way of writing characters.
I somehow feel bad about it because often when I write, I'm like "you shouldnt do this, this is GRRM way of writing, find your own!", but it was such a perfect idea of yours, this PoV system that I really feel like I cant write otherwise now.
Well, that's it for my post, sorry for using this space for such silly things, but I really wanted to write this somewhere I'd have any chance of you to read it.
And, like millions of people think: thank you, thank you, thank you for those books... dunno what my life would be without'em!
